articles.headline: Nestlé Targets High-End Coffee by Taking Majority Stake in Blue Bottle
articles.snippet: The deal highlights the continued hot streak of artisanal coffee, whose rapid growth and fanatical customer base have continued to draw big business.
articles.abstract: The deal highlights the continued hot streak of artisanal coffee, whose rapid growth and fanatical customer base have continued to draw big business.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2002, James Freeman gave up on being a professional clarinetist and began pursuing his other passion, roasting coffee.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Oliver Strand

articles.headline: Finally, Some Answers From Equifax to Your Data Breach Questions
articles.snippet: How will people get refunds for credit freeze fees? What about those faulty freeze PIN numbers? After a delay, the company responded to our columnist’s many questions.
articles.abstract: How will people get refunds for credit freeze fees? What about those faulty freeze PIN numbers? After a delay, the company responded to our columnist’s many questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last few days, several hundred of you have sent me questions or tweeted about the Equifax breach and its credit freeze process. I don’t blame you, given that you’ve melted their websites and phone banks since the company announced last week that up to 143 million people may have had their Social Security numbers and other data stolen.

articles.headline: The Shkreli Syndrome: Youthful Trouble, Tech Success, Then a Fall
articles.snippet: Rule-breaking at an early age may point to the success of company founders like Martin Shkreli, researchers say. It may also foretell their undoing.
articles.abstract: Rule-breaking at an early age may point to the success of company founders like Martin Shkreli, researchers say. It may also foretell their undoing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rare is the gifted teenager who is not bored in high school. Yet few have signaled their boredom as extravagantly as Martin Shkreli, the pharmaceutical company founder who was sent to jail on Wednesday to await sentencing for a fraud conviction.

articles.headline: Trump Humiliated Jeff Sessions After Mueller Appointment
articles.snippet: President Trump’s dressing down of his attorney general at a meeting in May was the beginning of a tumultuous summer for the two men.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s dressing down of his attorney general at a meeting in May was the beginning of a tumultuous summer for the two men.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after learning in May that a special counsel had been appointed to investigate links between his campaign associates and Russia, President Trump berated Attorney General Jeff Sessions in an Oval Office meeting and said he should resign, according to current and former administration officials and others briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Immigration’s Sudden Re-Emergence Scrambles Republican Agenda
articles.snippet: President Trump’s tentative deal with Democrats has elevated the one issue that most fiercely divides Republicans, threatening the party’s broader agenda.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s tentative deal with Democrats has elevated the one issue that most fiercely divides Republicans, threatening the party’s broader agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders had muscled through their failure to repeal the Affordable Care Act, punted on the perennial brinkmanship over the debt ceiling and finally reached the one issue that all of the party’s factions wanted to be on, tax reform.

articles.headline: Trump Signals He Will Choose Approach on Iran That Preserves Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: The president, who did not take action that could have scrapped the nuclear deal, is moving toward using military and economic leverage to push back on Iran.
articles.abstract: The president, who did not take action that could have scrapped the nuclear deal, is moving toward using military and economic leverage to push back on Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump kept the Iran nuclear deal alive on Thursday as a critical deadline lapsed, a sign that he is stepping back from his threat to abandon an agreement he repeatedly disparaged. He is moving instead to push back on Iran’s ambitions in the Middle East in other ways.

articles.headline: Equifax Breach Prompts Scrutiny, but New Rules May Not Follow
articles.snippet: Credit bureaus have previously fended off attempts for more oversight, casting rules as onerous and unnecessary red tape.
articles.abstract: Credit bureaus have previously fended off attempts for more oversight, casting rules as onerous and unnecessary red tape.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a congressional hearing last week, financial industry representatives pushed for legislation that would chip away at consumer protection rules governing the three major credit reporting bureaus. Loosening those regulations “would provide economic stability” by capping the industry’s exposure to class-action claims, a trade group official testified.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley, Tara Siegel Bernard and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: More Than a Week After Irma, St. Martin Is Still Trying to Survive
articles.snippet: A Times reporter on one of the Caribbean islands hit hardest by the hurricane describes life without fuel, electricity, schools and a dependable food supply.
articles.abstract: A Times reporter on one of the Caribbean islands hit hardest by the hurricane describes life without fuel, electricity, schools and a dependable food supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND CASE, St. Martin — The woman carried a small suitcase, enough for her and her child to try to start over.

articles.headline: Google and Facebook Face Criticism for Ads Targeting Racist Sentiments
articles.snippet: Both companies said they would change how their ad systems worked in response to two separate news reports exposing the issues.
articles.abstract: Both companies said they would change how their ad systems worked in response to two separate news reports exposing the issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google and Facebook, the world’s biggest sellers of online advertising, faced sharp criticism on Friday for allowing advertisers to direct ads to users who searched for or expressed an interest in racist sentiments and hate speech.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: North Korea’s Threat Pushes Japan to Reassess Its Might and Rights
articles.snippet: The limits of missile defense and a pacifist Constitution are weighing on the debate over how Japan should respond to the North’s nuclear program.
articles.abstract: The limits of missile defense and a pacifist Constitution are weighing on the debate over how Japan should respond to the North’s nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When North Korea launched a missile that flew over Japan on Friday morning, prompting the authorities to broadcast an alert on cellphones and television, many people wondered: Why didn’t the Japanese military shoot it down?

articles.headline: C.I.A. Wants Authority to Conduct Drone Strikes in Afghanistan for the First Time
articles.snippet: The C.I.A. is pushing for expanded powers to carry out its own drone strikes, and the White House is said to favor the proposal despite Pentagon objections.
articles.abstract: The C.I.A. is pushing for expanded powers to carry out its own drone strikes, and the White House is said to favor the proposal despite Pentagon objections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. is pushing for expanded powers to carry out covert drone strikes in Afghanistan and other active war zones, a proposal that the White House appears to favor despite the misgivings of some at the Pentagon, according to current and former intelligence and military officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Trump’s Tweets About London Bombing Anger British Leaders
articles.snippet: The president suggested British intelligence officials were aware of whoever was behind a terrorist attack on in the London subway.
articles.abstract: The president suggested British intelligence officials were aware of whoever was behind a terrorist attack on in the London subway.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump seized on a terrorist attack in London on Friday to promote his ban on travel to the United States by Muslims and, in the process, ran afoul of Britain by claiming without evidence that the assailants had been “in the sights” of the British police.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: SoFi Board Says C.E.O. Is Out Immediately Amid Sexual Harassment Scandal
articles.snippet: Mike Cagney, the company’s chief executive, had said earlier this week that he would step down at year’s end.
articles.abstract: Mike Cagney, the company’s chief executive, had said earlier this week that he would step down at year’s end.
articles.lead_paragraph: Social Finance, a privately held online lender and technology start-up, said on Friday that Mike Cagney would step down immediately as chief executive, accelerating a departure announced this week amid a sexual harassment scandal.
